text: thank you very much for coming to this talk i'm very excited to share this talk it's a new one that i've built specifically for qcon um
before i sort of start i want to talk about two significant experiences i had in my career very early on so i've been
working in technology for almost 20 years and so this experience kind of happened just after the dot-com crash
maybe some of you remember this so i actually had a job coming out of university and actually i lost that job
before i even started because they shut their office down that's how it was where i was growing up in australia um
and so it was kind of this sort of 2001 2002 period where you know things are a little bit uncertain
the whole dot-com bubble had sort of uh burst um and i had this experience working for
a large uh company i'll call it enterprise a and in enterprise a i was working on a
healthcare platform this was kind of exciting because healthtech is quite important and it felt like something that we could
actually build and release and make changes to sort of hospitals to governments to help people uh get access to a health
tech platform um but you know as an engineer i was spending uh three or four months
on calls with san francisco and india going through 200 page specifications you can imagine
how fun that was as a developer this healthcare platform had a two-year project plan so this was constantly
being updated but you could imagine this whole uh sort of plan and these people building this plan of
trying to get a healthcare platform early to test get it sort of regulated it's a lot of work
but you know we weren't going to see first customer uh using this platform for two years and so that's quite a long
can you still hear me yeah there we go um and what was interesting is that everyone had opinions in this and if
you've worked in technology you have lots of people with opinions right there's a saying about hippos the highest paid
perspective um and obviously this was kind of the age before agile and so we had a lot of different handoffs so 200
page specifications written by product managers we still had a build and release team who would
frantically put together build candidates if you can imagine what that was like or if you worked in that environment you know what that's like
and then of course that very rigorous qa intense phase where we have sort of stable builds
relatively stable builds and intense testing so that was a really interesting life-forming moment that i'm
lucky that i experienced very early in my career now a couple years later after i left
that enterprise i ended up joining a startup and this was kind of interesting because startups at least in
australia were quite rare and here we're actually practicing a lot of the sort of extreme programming principles and practices so
we actually had a user researcher with us who was actually doing user testing back then trying to test out new types of
prototypes to understand what would be a lot more appealing to people we actually released every two
weeks so this is before cloud we released every two weeks we prepared a candidate we got it ready and actually put this
out live and then we actually tested to see how our sort of changes actually performed with users we
had monthly ideation settings so we didn't have lots of people throwing ideas and backlogs of ideas
we all actually generated sort of ideas or hypotheses about what we think would actually have the biggest movement being
on sort of customer sign up or customer conversion and actually trying to test that out and we as developers were doing the full
life cycle thing of actually doing production support as well now these two contrasting experiences
for me were really life-changing because as an engineer i'm sort of thinking about what environment do i
thrive in the best where do i get this full size
make sure that i'm actually working on sort of the environment i want to have and this is the challenge that you will
probably face when you're actually working with you know recruiting people or keeping people employed
engineers today have the choice of going wherever they like and so they're sort of implicitly
thinking about is this the culture i want to work in and therefore which of these two choices
would you actually go with or which of the many choices will they go with and you have an ability to influence this if you're a technical leader in
your organizations by trying to shape this engineering culture and through over my sort of 20-year journey i want
to share some of those secrets with you now um as cassie mentioned uh we have
these quests for secrets and i'll be your guide today so a little bit about my background i've been
working for about 20 years i did consulting with thoughtworks for about 14 years and then over the last two and a half years
i was cto and chief scientist for challenger bank in n26 where i could put a lot of the sort of
principles and practices we helped with a lot of clients into play growing an organization from 50 people to about 370
over two and a half years and that wasn't by chance because when you build engineering cultures you have to be really deliberate about it
now i had those two life-changing experiences early on in my career so i kind of understand what developers
want what engineers want to have and your responsibility as leaders or managers is to sort of think about this
environment you don't need to manage engineers your value-add is managing the environment so those engineers can do
the best things that they can and so these are some of the lessons that i want to share if you're interested i have a couple of other
books and i run a course for tech leadership and also a newsletter
for leaders in tech but today i want to talk about the journey that we're going to be going on and really i want to talk
about why this is quite important why you should actually care then we're going to look at these three secrets and
we'll look at maybe some of the pitfalls with where companies go wrong and also what you can do for each of these
items and then also describe some specific things that you can take away and actually put this into practice
so let's start with the sort of why let's have a talk about why this is actually important so if you've ever had to do hiring you
know what's really hard now as a startup cto uh in germany
starting with 50 people we had to grow really rapidly i knew that actually engineers have choices wherever they
like you know every team that i've talked to in most companies are trying to hire somewhere
right so ideas are not the problem in our industry our our problems are actually being able
to build something to sustain it and also to experiment so ideas are cheap implementation's a lot hard
and you know we're all trying to hire maybe we're trying to grow talent which is also a great way but we just don't have enough so there's
a big supply and demand problem in our sort of industry for engineering talent um and as i said
ideas are cheap and easy you can brainstorm hundreds of ideas but actually it's only one or two of those things that you'll actually be able to
put into production and actually test and so your responsibility is thinking about where does software belong and how do
you help it sort of grow in your sort of company in a sustainable way and that's where engineering culture
matters and this is where all of you as tech leaders have an ability to influence it because your sort of ability to support
this is what will matter when you're trying to actually hire people and so we have you know the supply of
sort of developers over here and we have all these vacancies and we're all competing almost with each other
and it's your responsibility to decide what sort of engineering culture you have so that you have the best chance of
attracting the developers that you're looking for so you get to craft and this is one of the exciting things about technical
leadership you get to craft the culture that you want to have to attract similar people or people who
want to work in that culture and experience that culture and you have the ability to influence it so it's a really exciting opportunity to
have so remember that everyone has not just two choices but often
10 or 20 different choices about where they'd like to work we work in a very global connected
easily mobile industry and it's my experience that you know if you're not sort of keeping this engineering culture
a competitor will probably hire your engineers away from you and that's why this is one of the biggest most important things you can think about
as you're trying to cultivate the right culture um in your sort of area so let's talk about three specific
secrets because these are the things that you're here for uh so we'll look at each of these different elements and we'll look at
each one uh one by one so the first secret really is about the secret of making sure that
you have impact and what do i mean by impact so if we look at this i think there's three different elements
of impact that i think make a difference to a strong engineering culture the first one is that as an engineer i want to have
impact with the customers i want to know that what i do is useful for the people that we're actually
selling our products for um i also want to make sure that i see the outcome of what i'm actually achieving and that
i've actually got some satisfaction that i've solved a certain puzzle we'll talk about each of these elements
now one of the interesting things i've seen with some customer impact stuff is you know some organizations set up
developers to be very far away from customers so maybe you have an army of user researchers some product people in the
middle and in those poor organizations where you still get handed a 200 page specification
the engineer doesn't feel that connection with that customer right and so this is one big trap that
happens in a lot of organizations and it's kind of hard to unwind because you have to often work through
organizational sort of hierarchies and different departments to actually move towards that
it's probably one of the reasons why we've moved towards a lot more of a cross-functional role and really trying to put that customer
perspective as close to the developers as close as possible so that's something that you should avoid if you're heading in this way if
you want to build a strong engineering culture another idea is this thing about feature factories right
so i've seen a lot of organizations where you have backlogs for years right you don't want to be in that world
engineers definitely don't want to be in that world i asked you for that's the feature
factory right engineers join software because they want to solve problems they don't want
to just implement code they want to actually have a part in that process of taking a problem trying to be part of
that solution and really think about what it is the simplest way to solve that solution
through maybe some coding application but you know if they just have features to implement that's no fun as an
engineer so that's something else to avoid another perspective is sometimes people get too solution focused right
so uh this happens when you have a lot of product managers building lots of ideas about what could
be done so you know that there's a customer need but somebody's come up with that perfect solution about what needs to be done there's no
negotiation around it and once again engineers want to be part of this sort of problem-solving
perspective what about seeing the outcome what are some pitfalls that a lot of companies go
down here well one is there's just too many hand-offs right so you know product people are handing
specifications off to developers developers are having things off to testers testers are handing things off to poor
sre or devops people and everyone's just continuing to work so as a developer
i'm not getting to see whether i make good decisions because i don't see the downward implication of where i'm coming from
once again this is a really hard thing to solve because you kind of need to have an ability to influence the
organizational structure and so this is something that you really want to try to remove of too many handoffs
another idea is slow feedback loops and this is one of the reasons why i think things like cloud
architectures continuous delivery have really helped to improve that when i worked in that enterprise with a
two-year project plan to get to a release i was really frustrated as a developer because i want to see the value of what
i'm actually doing come to life when i worked in a startup where we'd been releasing every two
weeks that's such a big step change from two years to two weeks because i actually can see this sort of
feedback loop and i can see the things that i do have been adding value so work on improving these feedback
loops and try to remove the slow feedback loops another challenge which happens when you have an organization
with a small set of developers and maybe lots of product people is that people are often allocated to
different types of products or projects right and so developers are often sort of context switching on one project to
another this happens very much in early stage startups because you're often very lean in your engineering team
but all this context switching means that a person who's working on something probably isn't getting feedback about
what they built previously is good quality actually solved the customer need and they're maybe not really focusing on
like what the biggest value is so be careful of some of these uh pitfalls
and then you know engineers join engineering so that you can solve this really interesting puzzle right
so you know um martin fallow just published an article about outcomes over outputs i get asked a lot
by business people how do you measure the productivity of teams right do you use velocity do you use
points oh my team is getting more points than your team that's a really bad measure because it's measuring output
and a lot of people who haven't been working software don't really understand you can come up with a really simple
solution it may take a little bit more time but it may be less work and the hard bit
is in thinking about how you approach the problem and how you solve this problem elegantly
but if your organization is measuring people by the number of tickets they complete by the number of story points your team delivers
by the number of features you pump out who knows if those features are actually having an outcome
to desired outputs for your company or you know the customer growth or customer engagement so really you want to sort of
invert this and stop focusing on the outputs these are just byproducts of our process they're no real measure of what the
outcome is that you have without output another thing that um you know i hear a lot and i'm one of
those people that i actually try to instigate some planning so i actually don't think all plans are bad but
one of the difficult things is when people have put together a plan they then want to stick to the plan that
they've built right and good planning processes mean that you adapt you know
that you're going to get your plan wrong but it gives you a basis of saying how far are we off our mark so i believe
in estimation not because the estimates and the date matter it's because it gives us a good idea about do we share the same assumptions
and what assumptions are changing as we validate our work and if you have organizations that are
just simply saying but you promised it by the certain date you're not going to be building a really good sort of engineering culture
and one of the things that often happens if you're working a feature factory focused on lots of work is this idea of
just lack of celebration and feedback so let's move on to the next task let's forget that we've actually achieved
something really great and let's just move on to the next feature the next sprint the next iteration
so these are all things that you can avoid uh if you're focused on this so the principle i use for this is
really cultivating impact by reducing feedback loops now what does that mean what are some
concrete examples of what you can do for this when i first came into n26 it was interesting because
we're a beta c bank so um you know like all of you could sign up as a
customer um and our engineers could actually get closer to the customer this is a little bit more
difficult if you're on a b2b platform where you're selling to other companies who then sell onto end customers
but one of the practices i encourage our teams to do is actually go sit next to our customer services people
right so they're in the same well they weren't actually in the same building but they're in the same city and you know it wasn't much effort to go
over for an afternoon listen to some calls understand what problems that people are actually having
and i remember one time we have this uh activity called get stuff done days so every six weeks two days people can
choose what they do a team went over to customer services they sat with customer service people listened to some calls
and an engineer went you know i didn't realize this was a problem i can fix this right now
and like literally in an afternoon fixed a customer issue that was plaguing customer services
right so the further away you are from customers the harder it is
this is a practice of shadowing cs that you can have to make sure that developers get closer to customers get
quick feedback about how their software is actually progressing another thing and this is one of the
reasons why i think agile has become really successful it's not because of big scaling methods
like safe or whatever it's because you get to deliver in small increments right so
uh any large uh um transition or migration project that you've ever worked on and you're not actually
delivering value in small increments it's going to destine to fail right so we've learnt this
through smaller sprints smaller iterations make sure you deliver small outcomes
because then we can use that to improve our plans and as developers you get really good feedback about
whether you're actually building something that's useful i've worked on teams that have released something into production after
say a month only to find out users don't use it and so they could actually can the whole project
rather than continue on with the plan because they've got real feedback around user sort of feedback
um okrs are a very controversial topic and this is a whole other talk by itself but one of my pet peeves
with how okrs are used is that they're often used by management through objectives so management through metrics
now if you use okr's well what you should be doing is making sure that okay ons are used for aligning the
organization and making sure that people understand here is how my work contributes
so most companies should have some sort of company mission a goal that they're trying to have and
every probably year or every six months there's probably sort of large initiatives or themes that your
company is focused on to maybe improve right so it's either maybe customer growth stability
or sort of customer conversion or activity right um but then when a developer is working
on a task it's hard sometimes to understand how is this linked to the bigger broader picture
right and this is where i think an effective use of okrs is really important because it's helping connect this
feature to some sort of initiative to the company mission and once again engineers want to have
impact they want to have purpose they want to understand why they're working on something and so okrs when done well
can actually have a very important effect on this the other thing is really about
accelerating release speed and frequency so how many of you have read the book accelerate
very good if you haven't i highly recommend it it comes from the research that has come from the state of devops
report that has been running probably for the last four or five years and they actually come up with some good
metrics about how you do measure the productivity of an engineering organization and one of them is really about this
sort of speed to release so you know if you can release every two weeks
if you can release daily hourly or on demand it's even better but you can't just simply release really
rapidly you also need some counter balancing metrics like making sure when you release you don't break
everything so there's also some things about like failure change on release so that you're
actually developing quality as well but this is one of the biggest lessons learned from both continuous delivery
and that book which is the quicker that you accelerate this feedback loop the better it is and the better your engineering
organization will be as a result so if you're looking for a big lever this is probably the one of the biggest
ones to start with it's a hard one if you've got really long release cycles but it's definitely worth it as well
so we'll look to impact as one of the secrets let's talk about another one of these secrets
and this is really about uh choice engineers love choice but maybe a little bit too much choice
sometimes right so when developers disagree they love arguing over about these abstract ideas but
choice is quite an important part because it's part of this sort of problem-solving uh perspective so
part of it is having some say and being able to say what the solution is um having a say in how i work as an
engineer right so this is i like to have a say about how i conduct my daily uh business um and then
also degrees of freedom now it's interesting because i don't say complete freedom and we'll come back to this in a bit so
around solution choice things to be careful of is when you're a large organization it's tempting to say you have to use
x framework right uh you get this the larger your organization is
is that you know you want to have some consistency across the organization so it makes sense that everyone has to use this framework but you have to be
careful because that can sort of backfire because it's removing choice from developers you know often people and you get this
if you have a separate sort of architecting group are making decisions and then developers kind of
get to just simply implement these decisions and that's really no fun if you're an engineer and you really want to make sure that
engineers are involved early so that they're part of that process of choosing how they build particular
solutions and then if that output is particularly predetermined right so here all the
tasks that you have to implement for a particular feature that's also not very great from an engineering
perspective in terms of how to work one of the interesting things after working in
agile environments for a very long time is i'm really non-prescriptive so i'm not going to go to a team
and say you have to do stand-ups at nine o'clock even though i've read a book on retrospectives i'm not going to say you
have to do a retrospective every friday i don't believe in that um so if you have a single way of working across your entire organization
that's a big smell you want to watch out for if you have prescriptive processes and it's okay to have them at the start
but if you're not actually improving your processes and changing it you're probably not actually living the agile values because
you're not improving adapting and if you're optimizing for an individual this
is really hard because as a individual engineer i might have my personal preferences
but as a leader and manager you want to optimize for the team and for the organization not for a particular individual right so
you have to be careful about sort of boundaries of freedom because one individual's choice might start to
impact the productivity of your team and degrees of freedom is hard because we want to give lots of choice you know
you hear this term about developer autonomy giving them lots of um power to sort of choose um but you know
you have to be careful about heavyweight rules and we're seeing a trend away from architecture sort of rules to
more principles to help people understand what uh a good decision looks like in their environment
i think there is something about too much freedom right so to say you can make any choice whatever you like
i've seen a lot of companies that say you can use whatever programming languages you like and then end up with 20 programming
languages when they have 10 developers you can imagine how that's going to be maintenance-wise long-term
um and there's an interesting balance between autonomy and alignment so my autonomy can start to step onto
somebody else's autonomy because i'm sort of making a choice that affects more than me and so this is where you as a leader are
trying to sort of find out the right boundaries of both aligned decision making and autonomous
decision making and if you don't really have a clear decision-making process this is another thing that sort of
fuzzes up the boundaries is that as a person you have a certain amount of decisions
that you can make for yourself but as soon as it starts to impact other people or other departments your decision making perhaps starts to become
less impactful right you can give input but you're maybe not the decision maker and to to be um to help improve this you
have to sort of describe what those boundaries are for where you are so the principle here is really
cultivating choice by making the right thing easy to do right so if you want people to use a
preferred framework make it easy for them to adopt it make it valuable right so that's the interesting thing if it's
useful people will come to it and that's one of the principles you can use uh here so the good thing here is you
should automate the basics right this is one of the reasons we're seeing a lot of stuff around developer productivity tools
uh you know internal teams that are really focused on building common libraries not because everyone's going to be
forced to use these libraries but just because they've solved this problem and my team can benefit it from uh that
immediately you know uh scripts that sort of automatically bootstrap new environments uh sort of new projects
make it easy these are examples of making the right thing easy to do that then help with you know then
building on the interesting choices um using architectural principles over
rules so the 12-factor um sort of uh 12-factor architecture
is a really good example of 12 simple uh things that you can explain that talk about sort of cloud native
or cloud um sort of friendly uh architectures right and so that's something we're seeing a lot with
different types of companies that are starting to adopt architecture principles is that your company is at a different
stage you're optimizing for a different problem and these are things that you can help articulate um
make sure that you set up the goal and step out of the way this is really hard right because we're often as developers
people who want to maybe come up with a solution for other people but actually if we really want to engage
with people what we should really be talking about is here is the problem that needs to be solved here are the constraints of how
we're trying to solve that problem you want to give that to the team and give them the ability to actually
problem solve that and too many places start to sort of take away that choice by actually already pre-determining the solution for
those teams and the best way that you can engage with developer choice is making sure that you're clear about
what it is that needs solving and also by what constraints should that solution be
um and then uh to solve the decision-making boundary be clear about your decision-making process
so for a decision that affects the entire organization you might decide rather than everyone
has a democratic vote everyone can give input but actually the choice will be made by a smaller group
of people who are trying to balance out the needs of all these different teams and groups right this is okay you don't have to
give everyone absolute input or sort of choices for every decision that you make
you just need to be clear about where those boundaries are and what types of decisions you have so i tend to think in terms of technical
decisions about those things that a team affects the things that affect uh sort
of a sort of subpar of a product and then things that are affecting the whole platform as well
and you want different levels of decision making processes depending on how irreversible the decision is and how
wide that impact will be when you actually make that decision so we've looked at impact we've looked
at choice what is the third secret let's have a look so this one
is really about improvement right so developers want to continually see things improve i
had a hard time thinking about specifically what this meant to me um but one is definitely about personal
improvement right so as a developer one of the common things that probably we all share
is we want to learn we want to grow right that's a that's a key thing um but also if i'm working for a company
i want to make sure that like our company is also improving right um you know if we're working for um
[Music] tesla we want to see movement towards automated
and then the other thing is really about the good work environment right so engineers will often complain and i
think one of the good things about a good engineering management group is making sure that people's complaints get addressed right
so engineers will often think about the things that they can't control the things that are in an environment
and to create a good engineering culture you want to see improvements in that environment as well and i see that as the core responsibility of management
so some traps around each of these different areas is if you don't have any growth opportunities engineers will leave your
company and it's a natural part of our process you see this with startups and you see this with companies who aren't growing
people will want a bigger role more responsibility and it's one of the challenges that you have as a leader is trying to find
something that's challenging for this person and sometimes that will be without uh across the boundaries of your company
they'll have to join another company in order to have that opportunity to really grow
um being careful about repetitive work so you know if something is repetitive invest in automating it or if it's
something that needs doing rotate that role so be careful about things that are just simply the same thing day
in day out because people will get bored and engineers need new challenges all the time so they feel that they're
actually learning another thing that happens quite a lot is really a lack of feedback and support
a common thing i hear from engineers is you know how have i been doing have i been
growing uh you know by the time that you get to like an annual performance review of some sort there shouldn't be any surprises and if
there are it's probably an indicator that your environment is not providing the right sort of feedback or support so make sure that
you address each of these things if you really want to help engineers grow um the other thing that can stop people
is really this fear of failure so if somebody makes a mistake and they get fired for it how safe do you think that environment
is for learning right you need to think about what causes that and how to create safety when people do make mistakes
because it's very rare it's a person that makes that mistake it's more about the system that allowed that mistake to happen and
that's actually a leadership responsibility so remember that board people will quit
and if you're not actually encouraging them to grow and finding opportunities to grow uh um they will leave you and they'll
find some other place where they can actually do that so what about traps to sort of steps to
mission well one of them is unclear priorities it's something that i see a lot in different organizations is
that if you haven't actually gone into an organization and you have clear priorities this is really confusing because you
don't really understand how your work connects to the broader mission um early on my time at n26 i actually visited
spotify new york and talked to one of their sort of senior directors and it was really interesting because i've got six levels of prioritization like that's
crazy but then if you think about it spotify is something like i don't know three or five thousand people
right and so once again it's interesting because you have different hierarchies of prioritization but it's very clear in the order of
those priorities so me as an individual i know if i'm working on something and it's not the top most priority i can
go point to the common source and say hey i think we should be working on this thing instead so i know i'm actually
helping the company move the way that it's going right and so this is something that you can actually influence
um make sure that you re-emphasize this mission that people are doing but also make sure
that they can understand initiatives so sometimes a machine can be too broad and abstract right too much of a big leap it's like
how do we know that we're moving to perhaps autonomous vehicles and then you could help people understand here is the initiative that's
actually helping towards that and this is why your task is actually helping uh move towards that task so try
to address this gap another thing that happens a lot is really in transparent information so
maybe you have priorities but maybe they're stuck in jira somewhere and nobody likes jira uh and so one of your tasks is really to
make sure that people understand where information is how to pull that information so they get the best out of
it right now traps around the work environment things to avoid here is these sayings about that won't work here
you see this in very large organizations that aren't used to lots of change oh we tried that and it was really
painful and no that won't work here again right and so you need a supportive environment to try things out because those things
will sometimes fail they'll be a bit painful but actually you need that environment to say well we don't know if it's going to work
out but let's see if it actually improves the environment if you wait for people to say can i do
this you know this is a big indicator that people don't feel safe or they're not encouraged to improve
their environment so asking for permission you really want people to ask for forgiveness right i
tried out this thing i'm sorry i think i stuffed up um you want people to continually improve their environment
and then once again this lack of feedback about you know what your company is actually doing to take in
employee feedback how many of you do something like culture amp measuring you know what's going on in your company
it's about a third so even when those culture am surveys come out how many of those you know people are
actually taking that feedback in and people are saying we're doing these initiatives based on your feedback
right often management will be so busy just getting those things done but they'll forget to connect their
initiatives to the feedback that actually happened and so make sure that you take in that feedback but make sure that you act on
it and make that connection to where that feedback comes from because it's going to be longer and people will forget right so the
principle here is really cultivating improvements by making small changes easier and this is something that all of
you can actually influence be in your team being with another team member or across your sort of organization
some concrete ideas are really making sure that you take actions from retrospectives my pet peeve
we talk about this topic it comes up again and again why does it keep coming up oh we didn't do that action from last
time i'm sorry all right so making sure that people follow up on actions is one of your
basic fundamentals really um making sure that you improve the system through post-mortems and i see
this with not just incident post-mortems but also from project post modems right
so some large-scale project that maybe didn't go so well you need to take the time out to
actually reflect on what things did go well so you can amplify those things and what things would you change
the next time your organization takes on a large initiative right and this takes time out because
rather than working on the next item you're really trying to focus on improving the system
and that's really worthwhile um creating forums is an important part so i don't believe in pushing everyone to
work in the same way what i do believe in is creating ways that people can pull advice from other
people who face similar uh scenarios so be it your guilds of people with same sort of functional
skills or be it at the end of an initiative or
some sort of brown bag or lunch and learn kind of learning session you really need to be thinking about what environments you create to sort of
amplify these so that people are aware oh yeah someone into my organization has already faced this problem and i know
who to reach out to in order to understand how they approached it right so these are some of the things that you can actually do
um and making sure that you define growth paths um you do this a lot in sort of early stage startups
where people are just doing everything that they need to do to keep the business running but then people will want to ask how do
i grow what's my next step what's my next challenge even in larger organizations you may
have these growth paths but what you're trying to do is trying to help people find out how does it apply to them in their environment what's the next
opportunity based on what they want to grow in so make sure that you talk about a different growth path and not just a
management track but really a sort of individual contributor track or a technical leadership track where people
can stay technical and hands-on that's a really strong indicator of a good engineering culture

across the organization by either removing uncertainty or by making something that is already a
